awd_titl_txt: State Prediction in the Presence of Input, State and Output Delays: Application to Compressor Surge Control Using Active Magnetic Bearings
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this research project is to develop new design methods for controlling engineering systems in the presence of time delays arising in the inputs, outputs, and states. These methods will help engineers alleviate the adverse effects of delays on stability and performance. Multistage centrifugal compressors are one of the most widespread types of industrial equipment, and consume significant amounts of energy. They are used to drive natural gas pipelines and are essential components for building heating, ventilation, and air conditioning systems. Application of the project results to surge instability will enable higher efficiency operation of these compressors, thereby lowering operating costs and reducing overall energy use. Through the Rotating Machinery and Controls (ROMAC) consortium at the University of Virginia, the research team will interact with engineers from major compressor manufacturers, to formulate and disseminate solutions to major technical challenges faced by the industry.

Conventional predictor feedback in time-delay systems leads to noncausal control laws when the input delays are larger than the state delays. Initial investigations indicate that it is possible to construct a causal state predictor even for this case. The fundamental idea is to partition the prediction time into sections that are each shorter than the maximum state delay, and carry out the prediction recursively over the prediction time. The resulting state predictor is causal, but infinite dimensional. The thrust of this project is to devise methods to safely implement the infinite-dimensional predictor. The results are expected to lead to powerful new tools for control of systems subject to simultaneous input, state and output delays. An integrated part of the project is to apply the theoretical results to the control of surge instability in multistage centrifugal compressors by use of active magnetic bearings.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this research project is to develop new design methods for controlling engineering systems in the presence of time delays, such as magnetically suspended compressors operating on a subsea oil field. Main research results include

  • a state prediction approach to solving the robust output regulation problem in the presence of input, state and output delays,
  • design of truncated predictor feedback for the stabilization of exponentially unstable linear systems in the presence of input delay,
  • design of truncated predictor feedback for the stabilization of exponentially unstable linear systems with multiple input delays,
  • designs of delay independent control truncated predictor feedback laws,
  • estimation of maximum delay bounds of linear systems under delay independent truncated predictor feedback,
  • design of an event-triggered delay independent truncated predictor feedback,
  • design of a time-varying feedback law and a switched low gain feedback law to improve convergence performance of the closed-loop system,
  • design of an adaptation scheme for the design parameter in the truncated predictor feedback to achieve regulation without requiring knowledge of the delay,
  • applications to the control of active magnetic bearing systems in the presence of time delays,
  • an output regulation based unbalance compensation method for active magnetic bearing systems with input delay,
  • truncated predictor feedback laws for a class of Lipschitz nonlinear systems with time-varying delay,
  • consensus algorithms for a class of nonlinear multi-agent systems in the presence of communication delays, and
  • solution of the consensus problem for multi-agent systems with input affine nonlinear dynamics in the presence of input delays.

The main results from this project have been documented and published in one book, one book chapter, 18 journal papers, and 9 conference papers, all of which have been peer reviewed.

In addition to the book and paper publication, we have also participated in several events for dissemination of the research results and to collect feedback on them. These events include:

  • Invited talk at Industrial Technology Research Institute, Hsinchu, Taiwan, December 2015,
  • Invited talk at University of Texas at San Antonio, September 2016,
  • Invited talk at East China University of Science and Technology, Shanghai, China, June 2017,
  • Invited talk at Virginia Tech, September 2017,
  • Invited talk at University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, October 2017,
  • Invited talk at University of Texas at Arlington, October 2017,
  • Invited talk at National Chung Cheng University, Advanced Institute of Manufacturing with High-Tech Innovations (AIM-HI), Chia-yi, Taiwan, November 2017,
  • Plenary speech at the 2017 International Automatic Control Conference, Kenting, Pingtung, Taiwan, November 2017,
  • Plenary speech at the 2019 SICE Multi-Symposium on Control Systems: International Symposium on Control Systems, Kumamoto, Japan, March 2019,
  • Annual conferences of the University of Virginia Rotating Machinery and Controls (ROMAC) Laboratory, an industry sponsored research consortium of over 40 member companies, June 2015, 2016, 2017 and 2018.

The project involved three PhD students. Two of them, including a female student, have graduated. The third student has completed his research and will defend his PhD dissertation in the next academic year.

The research results are expected to improve our ability to control active magnetic bearings in high speed rotating machinery, such as a magnetically suspended compressor operating in a subsea oil platform. In particular, the research advances the state of the art in control design in the presence of time delays. Unlike the classical prediction feedback method, which results in infinite dimensional control laws, the methods we developed result in finite dimensional feedback laws. We have also developed feedback laws that are independent of the information of the delays the system is subject to, thus rendering the feedback laws robust to the uncertainties in the delays.
